headline: Seared Ahi Tuna Steaks
description: Try this simple ahi tuna steak recipe for elegant slices of seared tuna that rival what you'd get at a fine restaurant.

video.description: There's no need to head to a fancy seafood restaurant to get your ahi tuna steak fix. Instead, try the top-rated ahi tuna steak recipe in this video that comes together in just seven minutes — no, seriously, all you need is seven minutes.
video.name: How to Cook Ahi Tuna Steaks | Seared Tuna Steaks

name: Seared Ahi Tuna Steaks

recipeInstructions.text: Pat tuna steaks dry and season on both sides with salt and cayenne pepper.
Melt butter in a skillet over medium-high heat.
Add olive oil and pepper corns; cook until peppercorns soften and pop, about 5 minutes.
Gently place seasoned tuna in the skillet and cook to desired doneness, anywhere from 30 seconds to 1 1/2 minutes per side.
Slice tuna into 1/4-inch thick slices to serve.

review.reviewBody: Do NOT overcook the tuna! 60 seconds per side then get it out of the pan.

Great start for a recipe and so simple it’s hard to screw up. Here’s my alterations and tips: 1. Do NOT add butter when you sear on high heat. It’ll burn and smoke. Just use oil, then add a pat of butter when the tuna rests after searing, right on top, so it melts into it. 2. I crusted mine with raw sesame seeds to add a bit of a crunch. 3. Use tongs to hold, turn, and sear all sides, 20-30 seconds each, depending on how thick you want the “ring” that’s cooked. 4. I omitted the salt since it draws water from the fish - you can salt after you sear, but the fish is plenty salty on its own for my taste.

Don’t judge the knife cut… BUT this receipt was so great! I ended up using pepper out of a shaker instead of pepper corn. 2 4oz. Steaks The steaks cook so fast, don’t blink an eye. I think for my first time I did a fantastic job and many thanks to this recipe!
I didn't have any cayenne on hand, which is crazy living in Louisiana, so I used Korean powdered pepper which is hotter. I put it on after the tuna was done.
Easy and Delish!!
I made this recipe for the first time when I was running short on time…so easy and DELICIOUS!!!
The Ahi Tuna I had was about 1½ inches thick. I cooked for 1½ minutes each side. It came out great. My wife loves fish and I'm glad I used this recipe. Quick and easy, and very delicious.

A terrific quick part of a light meal. Other than being a bot too salty, definitely yet another recipe to keep close for re use, cutting the salt down to 3/8 t. Works well with fresh seasonal asparagus.
Excellent! We added some white wine to the pan after the fish was cooked and deglazed the pan for pouring over the fish. This is a keeper recipe!
Super quick dish but it was my first time searing anything so its not rare oops lol

We've made this many times now. It's a great recipe when you want to make something quick but healthy and delicious. As others noted, we now cut way down on the salt, otherwise have made it as is. But like reading others' ideas for additions (glazes) and look forward to trying those too!

Great simple recipe. Freaking delicious. Of course you need excellent ahi. Got mine from Green Acres in Simi Valley. Best seafood and meat. But anyway, this is a great recipe. Too many try to do too much. Fresh wasabi is great if you can get it.
Prepared as directed but omitted the cayenne. Loved the peppercorns!

Oh, My Word! Bethany Joyful, thank you for this recipe, it has converted me!! I’m officially an Ahi Tuna lover now. 

My Sweetheart made this for my birthday dinner, following the recipe exactly. While the peppercorns were softening and popping in the hot butter and oil, my tastebuds were sizing up the flavors headed their way. Once the tuna steaks were added to the pan, the cayenne pepper that had been sprinkled on the steaks made its presence known. My taste buds and tum were so ready to have this dinner and it did not disappoint! I immediately requested we have it again soon... like the following week... YES, the FOLLOWING week, I couldn’t wait to have it again. 

Needless to say, we’ve had this a lot now. We’ve had it with Cilantro Lime Rice and veggies and we’ve had it with Rice Pilaf and veggies. It was just as delicious with Long Grain & Wild Rice and veggies. 

The peppercorns make the dish for me. The second time we had this we decreased the salt slightly but increased the peppercorns to ensure there were some left to top the rice with (after topping the tuna.) We’ve used several types of peppercorns. We’ve found that Tellicherry black peppercorns add a very enjoyable softened/popped texture and a palate-pleasing complexity to the peppery flavors. 

This recipe is just plain delicious! Thank you again for sharing.
11/6/21 Very quick and easy to prepare.
Great recipe and easy, just way too salty. Cut in half.

Not much you can do with frozen tuna steaks from Walmart but this recipe saves the day. I used Zatarains Blackened Seasoning in lieu of cayenne pepper and table salt over the course kosher. Great for salads. Love this site.

I deleted the cayenne because I didn’t want to overwhelm the flavor or the fish. Used more butter and olive oil in order to sear all the edges first then a minute and half on each side. Coated edges with sesame seeds before frying.
What a great recipe. Simple yet tasty. If you like Tuna you will love this recipe.
Perfect and quick. I put his in the pan for 90 seconds before I put mine in. He likes his cooked medium and I like mine rare. Will make this again. Served with bock choy salad.
cooks so fast! taste ok...would like it marinated in italian dressing better I think.
Way too good
Husband and I loved it! Will definitely be cooking again!
I went a little lighter on the peppercorns. Plus they didn't really open up like I wanted so I poured them in a pestle and used a mortar to make them finer. Worked very well.

Super easy and so good. I double the butter and olive oil as I like to pour that and the cracked peppers over the top of the tuna steak. Serve with sticky rice, wasabi and soy sauce for dipping and roasted zucchini. Just yum all over this meal.

Make sure ur skillet is HOT!!!
I ALSO added 1 tbl of sesame oil and 1 tbl of honey to the marinade for balance.... Cut the salt back to half a teaspoon and add half teaspoon of galric powder (fresh garlic will burn in the HOT pan)

Simple and fast! I didn’t use as much salt, just seasoned to my preference. The first time I tried this I put the butter and olive oil to cook the peppercorns but found that the butter burnt and made a black smokey mess. Cook the peppercorns in just the olive oil and add the butter when you’re ready to add the steaks seem to work out better for me. I cooked them for 1 minute and 30 seconds on each side and they came out perfect! Thanks for the recipe!

Now I know why there are so many reviews—this is a fantastic recipe, easy and full of flavor. I cooked the peppercorns for 7 minutes over med high heat. The peppercorns never popped, but they were perfectly cooked and pleasantly chewy. This will be my go-to for quick tuna steaks from now on.
Too much cayenne but still good
Simple, fast, and delicious; the peppercorns really enhanced the flavor!

Delicious and simple. We cooked the steaks in a pan, but outside on the grill to avoid smoking up the kitchen. We added a little sesame seed, along with the salt and cayenne pepper, before cooking. Just our preference. The whole peppercorns really made this dish. Thanks for this great recipe!
Made as directed. It turned out yummy!!

This went over very well with my family. It was easy and I will make it again. I didn't get the crust of black pepper like in the photo. My peppercorns didn't pop open, but the flavor was still good. It would be helpful to know the thickness of the tuna steaks for the cooking. I had somewhat thin steaks (maybe 3/4 inch) and 1-1/2 minutes on each side was too long for my liking. The tuna was not overcooked, just more cooked than I wanted. Still moist and tasty. As for the salt and cayenne, I mixed them together before sprinkling on the fish to my liking. I added the extra to the Sweet and Spicy Swiss Chard (also from this site) which I served with the tuna.

Great recipe but actually don't need as much salt as he recipe calls for. If you coat the fish in sesame seeds it will improve the cooking process, taste, and prevents sticking. Also, people have complained of the smokieness it produces in the house. That is because olive oil has a low burn temperature. Replace the olive oil with avocado oil and that won't happen.

Delicious! 
I need to make sure the thickness of the steaks match, in order to time the cooking better. 
I mixed up a little Wasabi and soy sauce for dipping. May try ponzu or teriyaki next time. 
This is a keeper.
Really great, used cracked pepper,warmed pepper corns at lower temp. But rest of recipe as is was very good
This was a super easy recipe with minimal ingredients. Used cracked peppers and topped with a pineapple/avocado salsa which complemented it well!

I was a bit worried about the smoke smell as my wife is ultra sensitive to smells and hates fish; and there were posts indicating a heavy smoke problem. The key for me was a cast iron pan and just babysitting the oil and peppercorns. You will smell and hear when things are about to go south if you heat a cast iron on medium low and occasionally swirl the oil and peppercorns. Smell and hearing is the best indicator for me - it starts to sound like a bacon sizzle and smell like burning - throw your tuna in then. My wife only came out to make sure I had opened the windows, I wasn't yelled at.

Excellent, easy, very tasty recipe. My husband said it was the best ahi tuna meal he ever had. I took comments from other reviewers and, 1) adjusted the salt to 2/3 the quantity), then 2) added the white wine and made the reduction... this brought the taste over a notch... Very gourmet! Thanks.

This was my first time making seared ahi tuna...this recipe rocked! I used avocado oil instead of olive oil because of the higher smoke point. I served it with a simple dipping sauce of tamari and rice wine vinegar. Delicious appetizer for a seafood meal!

I've made this probably a dozen times since finding this recipe, and it's become one of my favorite meals. It always surprises and impresses the friends I make it for. I definitely use more cayenne and black peppercorns than the recipe calls for, and I aim for the steaks to be rare. They cut apart into natural strips with just a fork and are so much easier to chew than beef steak!

This is so easy and tasty. We like the peppercorn treatment so added a few more and didn't add the butter until we were just about to put the fish in to keep it from burning. We have a fennel rub we tried on the fish the 2nd time (gift we're trying to figure out how to use since we don't eat meat ) still using the salt/cayenne) and we'd use it again. This is definitely a keeper and will be the primary way we make tuna steaks going forward.
Delicious. I cooked a it longer for medium only slightly pink in the middle.

Mad good, crunchy cooked pepper corns are so good. I love pepper so I used a little extra, follow the directions and you'll be fine. make sure to season the steaks well with the cayane pepper and salt.
I left out butter to cus smoke. Peppercorns did not pop so I used a muddler. 45 seconds each side . Perfect . Thanks

I didn't use any salt and definitely more than a pinch of cayenne. The skillet must have been too hot because I also got way more smoke than I wanted in the kitchen. However, why I didn't give a 5* rating was because it was cooked too long. Next time no more than a minute on each side! I used yellowfin tuna steaks.

Get your pan hot! Recipe calls for Med-high but that is a somewhat relative statement. I used a vortex charcoal accessory on my weber grill and a black cast-iron pan. I could have gone hotter but it tasted great.
So easy and delishous!

I LOOOOVED making this!! Waiting for the peppercorns to pop was fun and very tasty!!! Make sure you wait long enough for them to pop so they fall apart and keep a close eye on your tuna! I made a grape salsa to go along with it. Excellent combo and very healthy!

This recipe was amazing! I didn’t have any cayenne, and I did add a few sprinkles of ground ginger. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly! I served it with steamed rice and stir fried mushrooms with bok Choy. This one is definitely a keeper!

This was so simple and absolutely delicious. I seared mine for about a min and a half for the top, 1 min for the bottom, and 15 sec each on each of the sides all on med-high heat (7 on my dials for my stove). I didn’t have cayenne pepper or peppercorn like I thought so I seasoned with salt, a light dusting on each side with Creole seasoning, and Some black pepper sprinkled directly onto the tuna. I also didn’t have olive oil so I used canola. I was super happy that it still turned out good because I never cooked a tuna steak before. I know I went off the rails on this recipe, but I still feel like it helped me to make a great meal and to be confident to make it again. 

I served mine over a bed of coconut jasmine rice and topped it with a mango avocado salsa that I made the day before.
Made some yum yum sauce to go with it.

took ChefJulianP excellent advice: less salt, don't salt until time to cook, add a little wine to the pan with the fish, cook 1.5 min on each side, remove fish and add a little more wine to pan to deglaze, pour over fish. Delicious! Will definitely make this again

Thank you Bethany Joyful,
Last night, 7/31/20, Cheryl and I thoroughly enjoyed your seared ahi tuna steaks served over rice pilaf with a kale salad and peach cobbler for desert. We added white wine while grilling the steaks in our iron cast skillet. We bought frozen Wild Caught Ahi Tuna steaks at Sam's and ate two of eight in the package. Great product and deal.

I love tuna so I was excited to try this. I was worried about the cayenne and salt not giving enough of a flavor (so it wasn’t just spicy) so I added less salt and added grounded pepper to both sides of the tuna along with a little salt and cayenne. I always compare tuna to the seared tuna appetizer from outback which is my favorite. I had to cook the peppercorns longer, some of them popped. I honestly don’t know if the peppercorns gave much flavor to the tuna after taking them out of the pan before serving the tuna, but I think adding ground pepper helped. It was quite spicy, I would’ve liked more ground pepper and less cayenne but it was enjoyable either way! I made mine with wasabi mashed potatoes and spinach. Wasabi mashed potatoes definitely gave everything else an extra kick!
I made it exactly as stated and The Ahi steaks were delicious. I bought thick, fresh steaks and I cooked them Medium Rare. We will be delighting in this meal again soon.

An easy recipe for a beginner cook that was fun to create and tasted yum! I actually seared it a tad too long but that was the fault of my computer that glitched at the exact moment the video was to advise how long to sear for. I will definitely be attempting this dish again in the future.
Alright recipe but WAY TOO hot. And 1.5 minutes a side is well done in my books. Fail.
Super easy!! My husband absolutely RAVED about how perfectly cooked they were! A total Winner!
This is a perfect recipe. I drizzled toasted sesame seed oil and fresh pineapple juice on it with some chunks of pineapple on the side. Just that much tastier!
easy to follow, simple ingredients, big flavor.
Easy and delicious. Yes, I will make it again.
My family LOVES this meal. It's so quick and easy.
Easy and delicious!
My husband and I loved it!! I used cracked pepper and rubbed it all over the tuna along with the cayenne!! Was the best ever!!! Can’t wait to make it again!!
Made as indicated and was well received. I didn't make any significant changes other than reducing the cooking time.
Easy and yummy. Next time I may try to crack the peppercorns more before adding the tuna
I did it with less pepper. Came out good. Definitely I will do it again
I would recommend using a neutral oil that can withstand higher heat. I would also suggest adding the butter with the tuna steaks so it doesn't burn. I thought it would be more flavorful as well.
Great recipe, so easy and tasted great!
I was always overcooking my tuna, this recipe showed me the correct way to make it.
It was good except I didn't buy sushi grade ahi. I think it would have made a difference.
Turned out great! I did not use the peppercorns and seasoned my tuna steaks with Teriyaki sauce before searing.

The first thing I noticed about this recipe, they had you searing the steaks in olive oil over high heat. Of course it is going to smoke! Use a high smoke oil like canola, peanut, sesame, grape seed, etc. I didn't have whole peppercorns so used coarse ground pepper, minimal amount of salt and heated cast iron skillet before adding butter and oil. Perfect!
no cayenne... delicious!
Simple and delicious! We loved it!
Try Tony’s Cajun spices. Less work and the whole family loves it more. Thanks for the recipe.
Great recipe. Season tuna after butter/oil is heating in pan. Only need to sear tuna about 30 seconds per side. Delicious.
Used seafood seasoning instead of spicy. Really simple and quick. I will make it again.
Simple and tasty. Watch out for the hot oil popping, though.

Very Good! Followed the advice of other reviewers and did not salt the tuna and only seared for 20-30 seconds. They were done they way my husband & I like them - Rare. Additionally, I would not sear the peppercorns unless you have a fantastic exhaust fan, as another reviewer stated the house became filled with smoke which could be very dangerous for anyone with asthma or respiratory issues. Next time I will eliminate that step & coat the outside to the tuna with course pepper instead.to get a blacked crust.

This was awesome. We like really rare tuna so I got really high-quality steaks and cooked 90 seconds per side. Perfect!!! The sauce is probably the best thing I ever tasted. Takes a while but worth it - I love it so much, I would drink it. So glad we have extra to serve with beef tenderloin later this week. 

I served this with cauliflower mash and Chinese green beans.

As written, I gave this a 3 star rating. Like others, the butter and olive oil mixed smoked the place up with the peppercorns. I wouldn’t put the fish in it. Tossed the whole mess and started over, leaving out the peppercorns and instead just putting freshly ground pepper on the tuna. As modified this way, it was a 5 star rating.
Tastes good. A little too salty but my husband loves salt so he enjoyed it with no complaints. 5 mins each dice for medium rare
Used sushi grade tuna, per fisherman, caught “hours ago”, Instead of just cayenne I used a seasoning mix of paprika, garlic, pepper, onion, cayenne, thyme. Perfect!!

I made it like 5 times, loved this recipe, it is super tasty and delicious, one of the best foods ever. I used sea salt instead of kosher salt three of the five times, the taste doesn't change at all.

Love this recipe. I have made it several times now. Sometime I use garlic oil instead of butter. Sometimes I add sesame seeds. The peppercorns don't always pop. But it always comes out good using this method. I usually go 2 minutes per side, since that is the doneness I like most.
I didn't have kosher salt so I used Himalayan salt. It was super simple and tasted good. Next time I will use less salt.
Super easy and super tasty. I had smaller steaks so I should've lowered the cook time to ~50-60s. Even so, they turned out great!
I followed the directions, and it was lovely. I topped it with Hoison Garlic sauce. I will serve this to company.

We made this the other night and it was delicious. The tuna steaks turned out perfectly (we heated the cast iron pan on the BBQ so we didn't have smoke in the house). 
I served the tuna with the mango salsa recipe from this site and some Thai lime (heat in the bag) rice.
Wonderful meal that could have been from any high-end restaurant. We will definitely be making this again.
No changes, will make again!

I'm just learning to cook, I substituted old bay for cayenne for dietary reaaons.
Yes it was very good and I will definitely make it again.
It turns out fantastic every time! I usually put the pepper in my spice grinder and hit it a couple of times because I have a difficult time waiting for the pepper to pop

This is a terrific receipt. For someone who never pan fried peppercorns in butter and good olive oil, it was a revelation. One variation which works for us is to sear a shorter time and then put into a low temp oven--250 degrees--until internal temp gets to perhaps 110. For those who like pure sushi, this may be a step down, but others may find attractive. The absolute key is to get good, fresh tuna.
I left the peppercorns out and it was delish! It was super easy to make and didn’t take long to make it. It’s a favorite of mine and the bride requests it frequently.
As a side dipping sauce - I mixed 1-1 1/2 tablespoons of Dijon mustard into about 2-3 tablespoons of beer into a dipping consistency. Delicious! I got this tip from a high end restaurant I frequent
I cooked this about 60 seconds on each side. Very tasty! You could blindfold me and I would have thought I was eating a nice steak.
Added a spicy homemade seasoning instead of the cayenne pepper. Squeezed fresh lemon on tuna during cooking and at end. Was delicious. Will make a again for sure.
